author: predated0
body:
I have seen Phillips, Trotec and Plasmamade being mentioned in active testing. Besides that, Microsoft and Ansys are closely following the project.   


Source: (you probably need to translate it through Google, but you can simply ctrl+f the above names)

[https://www.ed.nl/eindhoven/tu-e-onderzoek-biedt-sportscholen-hoop-apparaten-verwijderen-aerosolen-uit-lucht\~a0ea76e3/](https://www.ed.nl/eindhoven/tu-e-onderzoek-biedt-sportscholen-hoop-apparaten-verwijderen-aerosolen-uit-lucht~a0ea76e3/)  


As for sales, it's not for sale yet. People have been researching and developing this technology recently. The biggest issue is that purifiers are extremely costly and can cause more harm than good if they arent installed properly. They want to spend a lot of money on marketing to properly educate people how and where to install it, so I doubt its going to cost 45k$, probably more towards 50-60k$, but that is still a massive difference.

As for how it will end up performing on the stock market, I doubt the stock will keep rising, but I am fairly certain that it will at the very least spike once it is proven to have any positive results on covid, let alone that a lot of aging purifiers can be replaced with higher end hardware for the same cost.  


As for which ticker belongs to the company providing the new technology, I have no clue exactly, but according to other comments, there is vyst(for cheap play), LLC, trox, carr, jci(carr and jci might already be too late to invest), xiaomi, haier and midea(last three for china market). Not to forget the prototype companies Phillips, Trotec and Plasmamade ofcourse.

author: maxkingusa
body:
So basically Cathie said... if you liked these stocks 2 months ago, you should looooove them today.  She sees bigger gains now that they had these drops.  On one hand you want to puke up your lunch but on the other hand.... we should want this drop in tech and the chance to buy back the key growth companies.  

I bought AAPL, NVDA, AMD, AVGO, XLE and DB (to add some more financials and energy to my portfolio).  This keeps me balanced and I can wait out the pain that tech is providing.  

My biggest gains that I have held are from VIAC, SBUX, HP, JPM, STOR, LUMN, SPY, and a host of others.

Let's see if adding to tech this week will pay off.

author: milimiri
body:
You might want to remove STX, AVGO, AAPL and etc. from the list, and add ASML, LRCX, MU and etc. to the list. 


I am working in semiconductor industry but not in fabrication. Basically the most fabs have been out of game for advanced technology nodes. For example, TXN has some fabs, but they are old technology (still a descent market especially for analog chips). MU has fabs but mainly for memory (memory and logic CMOS are different in manufacting). There are also markets for power semiconductor, optical sensors and etc. For advanced SoC chips, only major players left right now are TSM and INTC. Samsung is still in the game and SMIC is trying to catch up. But basically TSM takes the majority of the market. 

Disclosure: I have been holding TSM for a couple of years. I personally prefer fab+fabless and I am a little bearish on US-based fab. But I am not an expert in the field.

body:
Its a fucking beast. Went from $60 in march 2020 to over $700 last month. It just did a 15 to 1 split. We are getting a hell of a discount right now. The underlying assets nvda, avgo, etc need fo come down a bit more and then this can rocket up. 

Tech isnt going anywhere. I work for fhe goverment. Needless to say we are behind the times technologically. And even we are now almost 100% work from home. We just got word that going forward our offices will be shared and we might be in once a week depending in demand starting in July.

Go look on the Nvida, Intel or AMD forums. Gfx cards are out of stock everywhere. Anything produced is swallowed up in milliseconds. SOXL will rise like the Phoenix from the ashes as it did in 2018, 2020, and now in 2021.

body:

I'm thinking Apple, SOXL, or NVDA. 
I'm new to semiconductors. But my thoughts are that a shortage of semiconductors will constantly drive the prices up. And I believe AVGO said they have a backlog that'll take until November to fix. So thw semiconductors problem probably won't be going anyone or it'll lead to new innovations. 
I also really like NVDA. And after their earnings report with no general movement I would think that their upward trend would start here
But then there is apple. Who i don't really think needs justification but I'd think would see the least gains in the short term since it would seem they have a lot planned for the long term

author: nunu10000
body:
+1 to Microsoft. They tend to sell massive "here's the whole enchilada" deals to customers at millions of dollars per year. Individually, the products are cheaper than their competitors, but in license and SKU volume, they make WAY more money. It's this bundled undercutting that drives so many organizations to move to Microsoft products. The conversation suddenly becomes, why pay "X vendor $300,000 for this thing, when Microsoft will include it in a suite of 4 other things for $120,000 more?" 

They're also putting a billion dollars a year into security R&D, and they're slowly starting to compete with more cybersecurity vendors.

Windows Defender has a Vulnerability component: competes with Rapid7 and Tenable.

Azure Sentinel will eventually compete with Splunk (not there yet, IMO, but eventually)

Windows Defender also has a EDR and AV component: competes with Crowdstrike, SentinelOne, (VMware) Carbon Black, McAfee, Broadcom/Symantec, etc...

author: MicroChapLong
body: About 9 years under your methodology assuming 10% annual FCF growth. But let me try a different angle here. How many companies do you know whose annual share price return equals their FCF yield? The majority of a company’s value is often in its perpetuity growth, or let’s say sustainability of its growth as well prior to the perp g period (sustainability relating to a required return which reflects risk as you alluded to earlier). So if starting from 6.5% (again very rare for a company growing 10% top line which should say something about simply using present FCF yield to say that’s the return I’ll get), combining that with high growth and what I believe to be sustainable growth based on strong competitive positioning and secular megatrends, the return will be north of 6.5%. My hope with AVGO is that a tech rotation knocks it down again and I can continue to add. Full disclosure my current basis is $360ish which looking back was obscenely attractive.

And those two (AVGO and NVDA) are the only ones that aren’t already pushing against the top of their current value (in my opinion), so those are your best bets on the upswing.

author: space1233123
body: Add avgo

author: wearahat03
body:
TSM is good but way overhyped.

Revenue in 2016 - 949

Revenue in 2020 - 1340

9% revenue growth p.a. 

ASML 19% p.a.

NVDA 24% p.a.

INTC 7% p.a.

AMD 23% p.a.

AMAT 12% p.a.

AVGO 16% p.a.

Being the technological leader doesn't mean the company is the best investment. 

In terms of stock price performance, TSM has been outperformed by NVDA, AMD, ASML and AMAT.

It's only grown revenues by 2% more than Intel per year for the past 4 years. 

If you measure EPS growth the story changes too, to the detriment of TSM.

INTC 22% p.a.

AMAT 29% p.a.

NVDA 29% p.a.

ASML 23.5% p.a

TSM 11.5% p.a

Other semis have done a better job not only in revenue growth but in their expenses / capital management. 

Even with technological leadership, I would rank them on the same level as Intel. What's the point of tech leadership if you don't translate it into revenues and profits?

Intel has lagged in tech but they're still able to grab revenues and profits. 

The best companies are AMD, NVDA, ASML because they not only deliver on tech but they translate it into growing revenues and profits.

body:
This \^\^\^

Salesforce has no legitimate competitors. As someone who works in a CRM-adjacent industry, *everyone* uses Salesforce. And there are still a significant number of enterprise level companies still implementing it and no one to really switch to. And they keep expanding their footprint with new modules. It'll be awhile before I bet against that company.

(Rant: this recent trend of great quarter results caveated with limited near-term guidance driving down valuable stocks is getting increasingly frustrating, e.g. CRM, TTD, CGNX, etc.) So short-term puts may work out, but for me long-term I'm buying more shares at a bargain - and/or a longer-term call (which I also did today). We'll see if I'm wrong...

author: therandomdave
body:
To test this, I setup a small 10 stock pie last Thursday and left it to run. Wanted to see the recovery from the dips last week and the percentage gain relative to spac performance.

Pie: AAPL, BA, CINE, EZJ, FB, TWTR, PACB, MARA, SQ, CRM

Fair mix of stocks, roughly 5% gain from Thursday.

SPACs haven't fared well, but that's because opportunistically during a correction they wouldn't pick up at all anyway. People have huge market bargains to get hold of and may be pulling their money out to go and get into stocks they think could make a quick turn around.

In the long run, there's nothing to worry about, there are simply too many SPACs and not enough gold standard targets right now to warrant huge pops on announcement but I'm sure that'll change over time, very soon hopefully.

author: spacenoodle2208
body: Crm feels super undervalued atm

author: BushLeagueQuant
body:
The best investments (stocks I've held for at least a year) I've had have come off about half a days worth of research. You can get into the ratios etc of a company but those aren't always going to mean a whole lot, a low P/E doesn't mean something will be a great investment.

Find a topic/sector you're interested in just read news articles, fundamental news and and events often effect price more than actual numbers. I've had a handful of +100% returns on single stocks in the past few years based of a single piece of news, below being the most notable.

- Splunk (SPLK) news about changing to a subscription pricing model
- Blackline (BL) signed deal with Salesforce for bundled selling
- Lowes (LOW) & Toll Bros.(TOL) changes in mortgage rates

P/E, EBITDA, EPS are important to backup some investments but a lot of the time they don't mean shit.

author: Ohyourenodaisy
body:
I've been eyeing these companies prior to this dip so I'll mention my ideas about them

Costco is great but seems to be valued properly for what it is. Nothing is changing for Costco, and they don't seem to want to embrace their online ordering.

I haven't done my dd on Walmart but they're positioned well, maybe the market didn't like the idea of $15 wage?

I just bought target at $178 so I wish I had waited a little more today but I'm still happy to hold on to them. They had a great earnings report, and I'm excited to see what bringing in Apple stores will do for them. In a time where b&m are sinking they found an excellent idea to bring in even more traffic

Redfin- the market hates real estate but redfin has the potential to rival zillow which is obviously trading much much higher. Personally, I like the idea they're going with of getting away from the need for a real estate agent for quite as many things. Many people are afraid that this year was literally the best anyone could do though. Low interest rates and most $ coming from refinancing that won't be there when rates continue to climb.

Salesforce I haven't done enough dd on but they seem to have a decent moat, not sure why they stayed low when everything climbed yesterday

author: outphase84
body:
Welp, your DD falls on its face here.

Salesforce's acquisitions aren't a result of trying to pump revenue on the bottomline, it's a combination of moving into adjacent marketspace without R&D investment, and staying competitive with competing offers.

Your Slack example is a perfect example.  Their valuation was $25B, and you need to pay a premium in order to acquire a company.  And the play wasn't a result of trying to get Slack's revenue or profit.  Microsoft has been pushing Dynamics *hard* as part of the O365 licensing model.  That's a direct competitor to SFDC.  And MSFT's message that their sales org is pushing is "We hit all of your software needs with one license."  The biggest driver of upsales on O365 are Dynamics and Teams.  Bundling CRM and UCaaS is a gamechanger, and has been wildly successful for them.

SFDC needed to be able to compete with that bundling.  So they bought the biggest competitor to Teams.  And they'll bundle it with SFDC licenses.

Tableau is a similar purchase.  BI is a huge play right now, and *also* a feature that MSFT is bundling with O365.  Adding Tableau into the fold allows SFDC to directly compete with MSFT on that front, too.

These aren't cookie jar acquisitions, they're competitive expansion via acquisition.

body:
> Slack shareholders will receive $26.79 in cash and 0.0776 shares of Salesforce common stock for each Slack share

There is a slight equity kick,  
but generally the merger partner does not move much after announcement. 

Probably Slack is moving with the CRM stock price now.
